DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Passenger Train, Truck Collide; At Least 3 Killed
Eds: UPDATES throughout with three dead, 17 critically hurt, fire, details on fog. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train carrying at least 144 passengers plowed into a tractor-trailer in dense fog, derailed and exploded today, killing three people and critically injuring 17, authorities reported. The engineer and fireman of the locomotive were killed when the engine careened off the tracks, overturned and exploded, the California Highway Patrol said. The CHP said the driver of the truck was also killed. CHP spokesman Bob Whitmire said 54 passengers were injured. He said 23 seriously injured people were taken by ambulance to hospitals, and 31 others were taken by bus to hospitals for examination and treatment of minor injuries. ``They still are fighting the fire in the engine,'' said Ron Baldwin of the San Joaquin Office of Emergency Services. ``They had a large fire in the engine itself and we're trying to get people out of the train in case there is an explosion. ``One problem is we have heavy fog and we're not able to air transport victims and it's making it a little more complex.'' Amtrak spokesman Arthur Lloyd said the train was going about 70 mph when it hit the truck, which apparently had ``ignored the lights and went right in front of the train.'' The train was en route from Oakland to Bakersfield. ``Our information is that the road crossing is protected by gates, bells and flashing lights,'' Amtrak spokeswoman Sue Martin said at railroad heaquarters in Washington. ``We do not know why the truck was on the tracks. We know the accident occurred id one car was on its side. It was unknown whether tule fog _ an extremely dense wintertime fog that has made San Joaquin Valley roads dangerous in recent days _ was a factor. Visibility was zero at the time of the accident, the National Weather Service said. Dense fog caused a 69-vehicle pileup near Tracy west of Stockton Monday morning, and a series of accidents involved 55 vehicles farther south in Merced County.
